column2: CHAPTER VII
column3: CHAPTER seven

column2: The same day, about seven o'clock in the evening, Raskolnikov was on his way to his mother's and sister's lodging--the lodging in Bakaleyev's house which Razumihin had found for them.
column3: The same day, about seven o'clock in the evening, Raskolnikov was on his way to his mother's and sister's lodging-the lodging in Bakaleyev's house which Razumihin had found for them.

column2: The stairs went up from the street.
column3: The stairs went up from the street.

column2: Raskolnikov walked with lagging steps, as though still hesitating whether to go or not.
column3: Raskolnikov walked with lagging steps, as though still hesitating whether to go or not.

column2: But nothing would have turned him back: his decision was taken.
column3: But nothing would have turned him back: his decision was taken.

column2: Besides, it doesn't matter, they still know nothing, he thought, "and they are used to thinking of me as eccentric."
column3: Besides, it doesn't matter, they still know nothing, he thought, "and they are used to thinking of me as eccentric."

column2: He was appallingly dressed: his clothes torn and dirty, soaked with a night's rain.
column3: He was appallingly dressed: his clothes torn and dirty, soaked with a night's rain.

column2: His face was almost distorted from fatigue, exposure, the inward conflict that had lasted for twenty-four hours.
column3: His face was almost distorted from fatigue, exposure, the inward conflict that had lasted for twenty four hours.

column2: He had spent all the previous night alone, God knows where.
column3: He had spent all the previous night alone, God knows where.

column2: He knocked at the door which was opened by his mother.
column3: He knocked at the door which was opened by his mother.

column2: Even the servant happened to be out.
column3: Even the servant happened to be out.

column2: At first Pulcheria Alexandrovna was speechless with joy and surprise; then she took him by the hand and drew him into the room.
column3: At first Pulcheria Alexandrovna was speechless with joy and surprise; then she took him by the hand and drew him into the room.

column2: Here you are! she began, faltering with joy.
column3: Here you are! she began, faltering with joy.

column2: Don't be angry with me, Rodya, for welcoming you so foolishly with tears: I am laughing not crying.	Don't be angry with me, Rodya, for welcoming you so foolishly with tears: I am laughing not crying.
Did you think I was crying?
column3: Did you think I was crying?

column2: No, I am delighted, but I've got into such a stupid habit of shedding tears.
column3: No, I am delighted, but I've got into such a stupid habit of shedding tears.

column2: I've been like that ever since your father's death.
column3: I've been like that ever since your father's death.

column2: I cry for anything.
column3: I cry for anything.

column2: Sit down, dear boy, you must be tired; I see you are.
column3: Sit down, dear boy, you must be tired; I see you are.

column2: Ah, how muddy you are."
column3: Ah, how muddy you are."

column2: No, no, Pulcheria Alexandrovna hurriedly interrupted, "you thought I was going to cross-question you in the womanish way I used to; don't be anxious, I understand, I understand it all: now I've learned the ways here and truly I see for myself that they are better.
column3: No, no, Pulcheria Alexandrovna hurriedly interrupted, "you thought I was going to cross question you in the womanish way I used to; don't be anxious, I understand, I understand it all: now I've learned the ways here and truly I see for myself that they are better.

column2: I've made up my mind once for all: how could I understand your plans and expect you to give an account of them?
column3: I've made up my mind once for all: how could I understand your plans and expect you to give an account of them?

column2: But, my goodness!
column3: But, my goodness!

column2: why am I running to and fro as though I were crazy...?
column3: why am I running to and fro as though I were crazy...?

column2: I am reading your article in the magazine for the third time, Rodya.
column3: I am reading your article in the magazine for the third time, Rodya.

column2: Dmitri Prokofitch brought it to me.
column3: Dmitri Prokofitch brought it to me.

column2: Directly I saw it I cried out to myself: 'There, foolish one,' I thought, 'that's what he is busy about; that's the solution of the mystery!
column3: Directly I saw it I cried out to myself: 'There, foolish one,' I thought, 'that's what he is busy about; that's the solution of the mystery!

column2: Learned people are always like that.
column3: Learned people are always like that.

column2: He may have some new ideas in his head just now; he is thinking them over and I worry him and upset him.' I read it, my dear, and of course there was a great deal I did not understand; but that's only natural--how should I?"
column3: He may have some new ideas in his head just now; he is thinking them over and I worry him and upset him.' I read it, my dear, and of course there was a great deal I did not understand; but that's only natural-how should I?"

column2: Raskolnikov took the magazine and glanced at his article.
column3: Raskolnikov took the magazine and glanced at his article.

column2: It lasted only a moment.
column3: It lasted only a moment.

column2: After reading a few lines he frowned and his heart throbbed with anguish.
column3: After reading a few lines he frowned and his heart throbbed with anguish.

column2: He recalled all the inward conflict of the preceding months.
column3: He recalled all the inward conflict of the preceding months.

column2: He flung the article on the table with disgust and anger.
column3: He flung the article on the table with disgust and anger.

column2: But, however foolish I may be, Rodya, I can see for myself that you will very soon be one of the leading--if not the leading man--in the world of Russian thought.	But, however foolish I may be, Rodya, I can see for myself that you will very soon be one of the leading-if not the leading man-in the world of Russian thought.
And they dared to think you were mad!
column3: And they dared to think you were mad!

column2: You don't know, but they really thought that.
column3: You don't know, but they really thought that.

column2: Ah, the despicable creatures, how could they understand genius!
column3: Ah, the despicable creatures, how could they understand genius!

column2: Your father sent twice to magazines--the first time poems (I've got the manuscript and will show you) and the second time a whole novel (I begged him to let me copy it out) and how we prayed that they should be taken--they weren't!
column3: Your father sent twice to magazines-the first time poems (I've got the manuscript and will show you) and the second time a whole novel (I begged him to let me copy it out) and how we prayed that they should be taken-they weren't!

column2: But now I see again how foolish I was, for you can attain any position you like by your intellect and talent.
column3: But now I see again how foolish I was, for you can attain any position you like by your intellect and talent.

column2: No doubt you don't care about that for the present and you are occupied with much more important matters...."
column3: No doubt you don't care about that for the present and you are occupied with much more important matters...."

column2: Dounia's not at home, mother?
column3: Dounia's not at home, mother?

column2: No, Rodya.	No, Rodya.
Dmitri Prokofitch comes to see me, it's so good of him, and he always talks about you.
column3: Dmitri Prokofitch comes to see me, it's so good of him, and he always talks about you.

column2: He loves you and respects you, my dear.
column3: He loves you and respects you, my dear.

column2: I am not complaining.
column3: I am not complaining.

column2: She has her ways and I have mine; she seems to have got some secrets of late and I never have any secrets from you two.
column3: She has her ways and I have mine; she seems to have got some secrets of late and I never have any secrets from you two.

column2: Of course, I am sure that Dounia has far too much sense, and besides she loves you and me... but I don't know what it will all lead to.
column3: Of course, I am sure that Dounia has far too much sense, and besides she loves you and me... but I don't know what it will all lead to.

column2: I shall know, anyway, that you are fond of me, that will be enough for me.
column3: I shall know, anyway, that you are fond of me, that will be enough for me.

column2: I shall read what you write, I shall hear about you from everyone, and sometimes you'll come yourself to see me.
column3: I shall read what you write, I shall hear about you from everyone, and sometimes you'll come yourself to see me.

column2: What could be better?
column3: What could be better?

column2: Here you've come now to comfort your mother, I see that."
column3: Here you've come now to comfort your mother, I see that."

column2: Here Pulcheria Alexandrovna began to cry.
column3: Here Pulcheria Alexandrovna began to cry.

column2: My goodness, why am I sitting here?" she cried, jumping up.
column3: My goodness, why am I sitting here?" she cried, jumping up.

column2: There is coffee and I don't offer you any.	There is coffee and I don't offer you any.
I'll get it at once!"
column3: I'll get it at once!"

column2: Mother, don't trouble, I am going at once.	Mother, don't trouble, I am going at once.
I haven't come for that. Please listen to me."
column3: I haven't come for that. Please listen to me."

column2: Pulcheria Alexandrovna went up to him timidly.
column3: Pulcheria Alexandrovna went up to him timidly.

column2: Mother, whatever happens, whatever you hear about me, whatever you are told about me, will you always love me as you do now? he asked suddenly from the fullness of his heart, as though not thinking of his words and not weighing them.
column3: Mother, whatever happens, whatever you hear about me, whatever you are told about me, will you always love me as you do now? he asked suddenly from the fullness of his heart, as though not thinking of his words and not weighing them.

column2: How can you ask me such a question? Why, who will tell me anything about you?
column3: How can you ask me such a question? Why, who will tell me anything about you?

column2: Besides, I shouldn't believe anyone, I should refuse to listen."
column3: Besides, I shouldn't believe anyone, I should refuse to listen."

column2: I shall never cease to love you....
column3: I shall never cease to love you....

column2: Well, that's enough: I thought I must do this and begin with this...."
column3: Well, that's enough: I thought I must do this and begin with this...."

column2: I don't know what is wrong with you, Rodya, she said at last.
column3: I don't know what is wrong with you, Rodya, she said at last.

column2: I've been thinking all this time that we were simply boring you and now I see that there is a great sorrow in store for you, and that's why you are miserable.	I've been thinking all this time that we were simply boring you and now I see that there is a great sorrow in store for you, and that's why you are miserable.
Forgive me for speaking about it.
column3: Forgive me for speaking about it.

column2: I keep thinking about it and lie awake at nights.
column3: I keep thinking about it and lie awake at nights.

column2: Your sister lay talking in her sleep all last night, talking of nothing but you.
column3: Your sister lay talking in her sleep all last night, talking of nothing but you.

column2: I caught something, but I couldn't make it out.
column3: I caught something, but I couldn't make it out.

column2: I felt all the morning as though I were going to be hanged, waiting for something, expecting something, and now it has come!
column3: I felt all the morning as though I were going to be hanged, waiting for something, expecting something, and now it has come!

column2: Rodya, Rodya, where are you going?
column3: Rodya, Rodya, where are you going?

column2: Yes.
column3: Yes.

column2: That's what I thought!	That's what I thought!
I can come with you, you know, if you need me.
column3: I can come with you, you know, if you need me.

column2: You see, I am glad to look upon her as a daughter even... Dmitri Prokofitch will help us to go together. But... where... are you going?"
column3: You see, I am glad to look upon her as a daughter even... Dmitri Prokofitch will help us to go together. But... where... are you going?"

column2: Good-bye, mother.
column3: Good bye, mother.

column2: What, to-day? she cried, as though losing him for ever.
column3: What, to day? she cried, as though losing him for ever.

column2: I can't stay, I must go now....
column3: I can't stay, I must go now....

column2: And can't I come with you?
column3: And can't I come with you?

column2: No, but kneel down and pray to God for me.	No, but kneel down and pray to God for me.
Your prayer perhaps will reach Him."
column3: Your prayer perhaps will reach Him."

column2: Let me bless you and sign you with the cross.	Let me bless you and sign you with the cross.
That's right, that's right.
column3: That's right, that's right.

column2: Yes, he was glad, he was very glad that there was no one there, that he was alone with his mother.
column3: Yes, he was glad, he was very glad that there was no one there, that he was alone with his mother.

column2: For the first time after all those awful months his heart was softened.
column3: For the first time after all those awful months his heart was softened.

column2: He fell down before her, he kissed her feet and both wept, embracing.
column3: He fell down before her, he kissed her feet and both wept, embracing.

column2: And she was not surprised and did not question him this time.
column3: And she was not surprised and did not question him this time.

column2: For some days she had realised that something awful was happening to her son and that now some terrible minute had come for him.
column3: For some days she had realised that something awful was happening to her son and that now some terrible minute had come for him.

column2: You would run like this to me and hug me and kiss me.
column3: You would run like this to me and hug me and kiss me.

column2: The first time I saw you, that evening, you remember, as soon as we arrived here, I guessed simply from your eyes.
column3: The first time I saw you, that evening, you remember, as soon as we arrived here, I guessed simply from your eyes.

column2: My heart sank at once, and to-day when I opened the door and looked at you, I thought the fatal hour had come.
column3: My heart sank at once, and to day when I opened the door and looked at you, I thought the fatal hour had come.

column2: No!
column3: No!

column2: You'll come again?
column3: You'll come again?

column2: Yes...	Yes...
I'll come."
column3: I'll come."

column2: Rodya, don't be angry, I don't dare to question you.	Rodya, don't be angry, I don't dare to question you.
I know I mustn't. Only say two words to me--is it far where you are going?"
column3: I know I mustn't. Only say two words to me-is it far where you are going?"

column2: Very far.
column3: Very far.

column2: What is awaiting you there?	What is awaiting you there?
Some post or career for you?"
column3: Some post or career for you?"

column2: What God sends... only pray for me. Raskolnikov went to the door, but she clutched him and gazed despairingly into his eyes.
column3: What God sends... only pray for me. Raskolnikov went to the door, but she clutched him and gazed despairingly into his eyes.

column2: Enough, mother, said Raskolnikov, deeply regretting that he had come.
column3: Enough, mother, said Raskolnikov, deeply regretting that he had come.

column2: Not for ever, it's not yet for ever?	Not for ever, it's not yet for ever?
You'll come, you'll come to-morrow?"
column3: You'll come, you'll come to morrow?"

column2: I will, I will, good-bye. He tore himself away at last.
column3: I will, I will, good bye. He tore himself away at last.

column2: He wanted to finish all before sunset.
column3: He wanted to finish all before sunset.

column2: He did not want to meet anyone till then.
column3: He did not want to meet anyone till then.

column2: Going up the stairs he noticed that Nastasya rushed from the samovar to watch him intently.
column3: Going up the stairs he noticed that Nastasya rushed from the samovar to watch him intently.

column2: Can anyone have come to see me? he wondered.
column3: Can anyone have come to see me? he wondered.

column2: He had a disgusted vision of Porfiry.
column3: He had a disgusted vision of Porfiry.

column2: But opening his door he saw Dounia.
column3: But opening his door he saw Dounia.

column2: He stopped short in the doorway.
column3: He stopped short in the doorway.

column2: She rose from the sofa in dismay and stood up facing him.
column3: She rose from the sofa in dismay and stood up facing him.

column2: Her eyes, fixed upon him, betrayed horror and infinite grief.
column3: Her eyes, fixed upon him, betrayed horror and infinite grief.

column2: Am I to come in or go away? he asked uncertainly.
column3: Am I to come in or go away? he asked uncertainly.

column2: We were both waiting for you. We thought that you would be sure to come there."
column3: We were both waiting for you. We thought that you would be sure to come there."

column2: Raskolnikov went into the room and sank exhausted on a chair.
column3: Raskolnikov went into the room and sank exhausted on a chair.

column2: I feel weak, Dounia, I am very tired; and I should have liked at this moment to be able to control myself.
column3: I feel weak, Dounia, I am very tired; and I should have liked at this moment to be able to control myself.

column2: He glanced at her mistrustfully.
column3: He glanced at her mistrustfully.

column2: Where were you all night?
column3: Where were you all night?

column2: I don't remember clearly.	I don't remember clearly.
You see, sister, I wanted to make up my mind once for all, and several times I walked by the Neva, I remember that I wanted to end it all there, but...
column3: You see, sister, I wanted to make up my mind once for all, and several times I walked by the Neva, I remember that I wanted to end it all there, but...

column2: Thank God!	Thank God!
That was just what we were afraid of, Sofya Semyonovna and I. Then you still have faith in life?
column3: That was just what we were afraid of, Sofya Semyonovna and i Then you still have faith in life?

column2: Thank God, thank God!"
column3: Thank God, thank God!"

column2: Raskolnikov smiled bitterly.
column3: Raskolnikov smiled bitterly.

column2: I haven't faith, but I have just been weeping in mother's arms; I haven't faith, but I have just asked her to pray for me.	I haven't faith, but I have just been weeping in mother's arms; I haven't faith, but I have just asked her to pray for me.
Have you been at mother's?	Have you been at mother's?
Have you told her?" cried Dounia, horror-stricken.
column3: Have you told her?" cried Dounia, horror stricken.

column2: Surely you haven't done that?
column3: Surely you haven't done that?

column2: No, I didn't tell her... in words; but she understood a great deal. She heard you talking in your sleep.	No, I didn't tell her... in words; but she understood a great deal. She heard you talking in your sleep.
I am sure she half understands it already.
column3: I am sure she half understands it already.

column2: Perhaps I did wrong in going to see her.
column3: Perhaps I did wrong in going to see her.

column2: A contemptible person, but ready to face suffering!	A contemptible person, but ready to face suffering!
You are, aren't you?"
column3: You are, aren't you?"

column2: At once.
column3: At once.

column2: It's pride, Dounia.
column3: It's pride, Dounia.

column2: Pride, Rodya.
column3: Pride, Rodya.

column2: There was a gleam of fire in his lustreless eyes; he seemed to be glad to think that he was still proud.
column3: There was a gleam of fire in his lustreless eyes; he seemed to be glad to think that he was still proud.

column2: You don't think, sister, that I was simply afraid of the water? he asked, looking into her face with a sinister smile.
column3: You don't think, sister, that I was simply afraid of the water? he asked, looking into her face with a sinister smile.

column2: Silence lasted for two minutes.
column3: Silence lasted for two minutes.

column2: Suddenly he got up.
column3: Suddenly he got up.

column2: It's late, it's time to go!	It's late, it's time to go!
I am going at once to give myself up.
column3: I am going at once to give myself up.

column2: But I don't know why I am going to give myself up."
column3: But I don't know why I am going to give myself up."

column2: Big tears fell down her cheeks.
column3: Big tears fell down her cheeks.

column2: You are crying, sister, but can you hold out your hand to me?
column3: You are crying, sister, but can you hold out your hand to me?

column2: You doubted it?
column3: You doubted it?

column2: She threw her arms round him.
column3: She threw her arms round him.

column2: Aren't you half expiating your crime by facing the suffering? she cried, holding him close and kissing him.
column3: Aren't you half expiating your crime by facing the suffering? she cried, holding him close and kissing him.

column2: Crime?	Crime?
What crime?" he cried in sudden fury.
column3: What crime?" he cried in sudden fury.

column2: That I killed a vile noxious insect, an old pawnbroker woman, of use to no one!...	That I killed a vile noxious insect, an old pawnbroker woman, of use to no one!...
Killing her was atonement for forty sins.
column3: Killing her was atonement for forty sins.

column2: She was sucking the life out of poor people.
column3: She was sucking the life out of poor people.

column2: Was that a crime?
column3: Was that a crime?

column2: 'A crime! a crime!' Only now I see clearly the imbecility of my cowardice, now that I have decided to face this superfluous disgrace.
column3: 'A crime! a crime!' Only now I see clearly the imbecility of my cowardice, now that I have decided to face this superfluous disgrace.

column2: It's simply because I am contemptible and have nothing in me that I have decided to, perhaps too for my advantage, as that...
column3: It's simply because I am contemptible and have nothing in me that I have decided to, perhaps too for my advantage, as that...

column2: Porfiry... suggested!"
column3: Porfiry... suggested!"

column2: Brother, brother, what are you saying?	Brother, brother, what are you saying?
Why, you have shed blood?" cried Dounia in despair.
column3: Why, you have shed blood?" cried Dounia in despair.

column2: Which all men shed, he put in almost frantically, "which flows and has always flowed in streams, which is spilt like champagne, and for which men are crowned in the Capitol and are called afterwards benefactors of mankind.
column3: Which all men shed, he put in almost frantically, "which flows and has always flowed in streams, which is spilt like champagne, and for which men are crowned in the Capitol and are called afterwards benefactors of mankind.

column2: Look into it more carefully and understand it!
column3: Look into it more carefully and understand it!

column2: But I... I couldn't carry out even the first step, because I am contemptible, that's what's the matter!
column3: But i.. I couldn't carry out even the first step, because I am contemptible, that's what's the matter!

column2: And yet I won't look at it as you do.
column3: And yet I won't look at it as you do.

column2: If I had succeeded I should have been crowned with glory, but now I'm trapped."
column3: If I had succeeded I should have been crowned with glory, but now I'm trapped."

column2: But that's not so, not so!	But that's not so, not so!
Brother, what are you saying?"
column3: Brother, what are you saying?"

column2: Ah, it's not picturesque, not aesthetically attractive!	Ah, it's not picturesque, not aesthetically attractive!
I've never, never been stronger and more convinced than now."
column3: I've never, never been stronger and more convinced than now."

column2: He felt that he had, anyway, made these two poor women miserable, that he was, anyway, the cause...
column3: He felt that he had, anyway, made these two poor women miserable, that he was, anyway, the cause...

column2: Good-bye!
column3: Good bye!

column2: We won't dispute.
column3: We won't dispute.

column2: It's time, high time to go. Don't follow me, I beseech you, I have somewhere else to go....
column3: It's time, high time to go. Don't follow me, I beseech you, I have somewhere else to go....

column2: But you go at once and sit with mother.
column3: But you go at once and sit with mother.

column2: I entreat you to!
column3: I entreat you to!

column2: It's my last request of you.
column3: It's my last request of you.

column2: Don't leave her at all; I left her in a state of anxiety, that she is not fit to bear; she will die or go out of her mind.
column3: Don't leave her at all; I left her in a state of anxiety, that she is not fit to bear; she will die or go out of her mind.

column2: Be with her!
column3: Be with her!

column2: Razumihin will be with you.
column3: Razumihin will be with you.

column2: Don't cry about me: I'll try to be honest and manly all my life, even if I am a murderer.
column3: Don't cry about me: I'll try to be honest and manly all my life, even if I am a murderer.

column2: Perhaps I shall some day make a name.
column3: Perhaps I shall some day make a name.

column2: I won't disgrace you, you will see; I'll still show....
column3: I won't disgrace you, you will see; I'll still show....

column2: Now good-bye for the present," he concluded hurriedly, noticing again a strange expression in Dounia's eyes at his last words and promises.
column3: Now good bye for the present," he concluded hurriedly, noticing again a strange expression in Dounia's eyes at his last words and promises.

column2: Why are you crying?	Why are you crying?
Don't cry, don't cry: we are not parting for ever!
column3: Don't cry, don't cry: we are not parting for ever!

column2: Ah, yes!
column3: Ah, yes!

column2: Wait a minute, I'd forgotten!"
column3: Wait a minute, I'd forgotten!"

column2: He went to the table, took up a thick dusty book, opened it and took from between the pages a little water-colour portrait on ivory.
column3: He went to the table, took up a thick dusty book, opened it and took from between the pages a little water colour portrait on ivory.

column2: It was the portrait of his landlady's daughter, who had died of fever, that strange girl who had wanted to be a nun.
column3: It was the portrait of his landlady's daughter, who had died of fever, that strange girl who had wanted to be a nun.

column2: I used to talk a great deal about it to her, only to her, he said thoughtfully.
column3: I used to talk a great deal about it to her, only to her, he said thoughtfully.

column2: Don't be uneasy," he returned to Dounia, "she was as much opposed to it as you, and I am glad that she is gone.
column3: Don't be uneasy," he returned to Dounia, "she was as much opposed to it as you, and I am glad that she is gone.

column2: The great point is that everything now is going to be different, is going to be broken in two," he cried, suddenly returning to his dejection. "Everything, everything, and am I prepared for it?
column3: The great point is that everything now is going to be different, is going to be broken in two," he cried, suddenly returning to his dejection. "Everything, everything, and am I prepared for it?

column2: Do I want it myself? They say it is necessary for me to suffer!
column3: Do I want it myself? They say it is necessary for me to suffer!

column2: What's the object of these senseless sufferings?
column3: What's the object of these senseless sufferings?

column2: shall I know any better what they are for, when I am crushed by hardships and idiocy, and weak as an old man after twenty years' penal servitude?
column3: shall I know any better what they are for, when I am crushed by hardships and idiocy, and weak as an old man after twenty years' penal servitude?

column2: And what shall I have to live for then?
column3: And what shall I have to live for then?

column2: Why am I consenting to that life now?
column3: Why am I consenting to that life now?

column2: At last they both went out.
column3: At last they both went out.

column2: It was hard for Dounia, but she loved him. She walked away, but after going fifty paces she turned round to look at him again.
column3: It was hard for Dounia, but she loved him. She walked away, but after going fifty paces she turned round to look at him again.

column2: He was still in sight.
column3: He was still in sight.

column2: At the corner he too turned and for the last time their eyes met; but noticing that she was looking at him, he motioned her away with impatience and even vexation, and turned the corner abruptly.
column3: At the corner he too turned and for the last time their eyes met; but noticing that she was looking at him, he motioned her away with impatience and even vexation, and turned the corner abruptly.

column2: I am wicked, I see that, he thought to himself, feeling ashamed a moment later of his angry gesture to Dounia.
column3: I am wicked, I see that, he thought to himself, feeling ashamed a moment later of his angry gesture to Dounia.

column2: But why are they so fond of me if I don't deserve it?	But why are they so fond of me if I don't deserve it?
Oh, if only I were alone and no one loved me and I too had never loved anyone!
column3: Oh, if only I were alone and no one loved me and I too had never loved anyone!

column2: Yes, that's it, that's it, that's what they are sending me there for, that's what they want.
column3: Yes, that's it, that's it, that's what they are sending me there for, that's what they want.

column2: Look at them running to and fro about the streets, every one of them a scoundrel and a criminal at heart and, worse still, an idiot.
column3: Look at them running to and fro about the streets, every one of them a scoundrel and a criminal at heart and, worse still, an idiot.

column2: He fell to musing by what process it could come to pass, that he could be humbled before all of them, indiscriminately--humbled by conviction. And yet why not?
column3: He fell to musing by what process it could come to pass, that he could be humbled before all of them, indiscriminately-humbled by conviction. And yet why not?

column2: It must be so.
column3: It must be so.

column2: Would not twenty years of continual bondage crush him utterly?
column3: Would not twenty years of continual bondage crush him utterly?
